text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with beef and barley stew that's
right if you were hoping for a
complicated hard to make recipe you're
going to be very disappointed with this
because while it does take a little bit
of time to make it is very easy and the
results are beyond delicious and to make
up for the fact this is so simple i'm
gonna show you a very cool trick later
for how to create some delicious edible
snow for the top of your winter stews so
stay tuned for that but for now let's go
ahead get started and for this we're
going to need some beef shank so i have
two pounds of beef shank that's two nice
thick slices we're going to go ahead and
generously season that with kosher salt
and freshly ground black pepper and by
the way while I'm doing this let me make
a point about choosing your beef shank
ideally what you're looking for is a
smaller bone with marrow going all the
way through the center all right you see
this one you see how big that bone is
and if we flip it there is some arrow on
that side but not all the way through so
not only did I pay for bone instead of
meat I cheated myself out of some bone
marrow which is one of the things that
gives us dish such a great flavor so pay
attention when you're at the butcher's
counter and make sure you're getting
some good ones and once our beef shanks
been seasoned generously on both sides
we're gonna Brown that very well in our
soup pot over high heat and a little bit
of vegetable oil and one tip here if
your shanks start to curl up in the pan
just slice through that membrane that
goes around the outside around the
outside and that will help it stay flat
as it Browns so like I said we're going
to brown those very thoroughly on both
sides over high heat at which point we
will remove those and reserve them will
then quickly turn our heat down to
medium and add one diced onion along
with a big pinch of salt and we'll saute
that onion on medium heat for four or
five minutes until it starts to turn
translucent and it should look all nice
and golden brown and by the way most of
that color is coming from the Fond on
the bottom of the pan and I know when
you think of deglazing you think of
liquid but actually we just use those
onions to deglaze the pot and then once
our onions are looking like that we will
add some chopped garlic and as usual
we'll just give that about a one-minute
sizzle we certainly don't want to brown
the garlic so like I said we'll cook
that for about one minute
at which point we'll add some tomato
paste all right couple tablespoons of
tomato paste we'll stir that in and
what's going to happen because that
tomato paste has a lot of sugar and acid
in it it's going to stick to and
caramelize to the bottom of the
and which is a good thing don't be
worried well actually let me take that
back you should be worried if it gets
too dark okay so don't walk away just
keep stirring keep cooking on medium
heat until your tomato takes out kind of
a dark brick red color and as soon as it
goes from that to a brown you have to
add your stock okay so right here I'm
going to pour in my chicken stock that's
going to stop any caramelization and
keep it from going any further so make
sure you have your stock or broth right
next to the pot when you're doing this
step so we'll dump in our liquid you
could also use beef stock or veal stock
or even water if you have to and then
along with the stock we will also add
some celery and carrots and by the way
if the color on those carrots looks a
little different that's because I bought
some heirloom red carrots and what's the
difference between those and regular
carrots about three bucks a pound we're
also gonna add a bay leaf and a little
pinch of dry rosemary and absolutely you
can use fresh but usually for these slow
cooking stew type things I do prefer the
flavor profile of the dried herb tends
to be a little bit on the must of your
side and I know that doesn't necessarily
sound like an advantage but it is and
then we can go ahead and add our beef
shank back in and of course Nestle it
down ideally we want all that meat
covered in liquid and there should just
be enough and of course it goes without
saying any accumulated juices will and
must be returned to the pot and then
from here on we're using standard stew
procedure we will raise our heat to
medium-high and bring this up to a
simmer
at which point we'll reduce it to low to
maintain a very gentle very slow simmer
and once you've gotten your heat dialed
in and it's bubbling gently we will
cover that and cook it until that meat
is fork tender which depending on the
size of your beef shank is going to take
two or three hours
alright mine took about three you'll
know when it's done because you're going
to uncover it and you're going to give
it the old poka poka with a fork and
right here mine was perfectly tender
also of course a big clue is that it's
falling apart and once you determine
yours is done and tender we'll remove
that meat and bone to a bowl and we can
move on to the final phase the cooking
of the barley I got myself a nice
package of Italian barley in fact this
one was being sold as Italian naked
barley which I have absolutely no idea
what that refers to but anyway I figured
why not and I gave it a try
and I'm going to add
one generous 1/2 cup and stirred that in
and you probably want to adjust your
heat to about medium here we want to
maintain a pretty enthusiastic simmer
not a boil but a good simmer and all
we're going to do is simmer that until
your barley is tender all right mine
took about 45 minutes but it could be an
hour for you could be more and just like
if you were cooking risotto or pearl
couscous or rice or another grain you're
going to decide how far to take it
personally I want mine tender with just
a little bit of texture to it and when
you determine your barley is perfectly
cooked we are carefully going to slide
our meat back in and Nestle it down and
all we're going to do to finish this off
is turn our heat down to low cover that
pot and just let it sit there for about
five or ten minutes until that beef
heats through at which point we're
pretty much ready to serve and I said
pretty much because you got to taste it
might need a little more salt of course
you're the chief of your barley and beef
so taste and adjust and once you have
that seasoned just right it's time to
dish up and I'm going to finish mine off
with a little bit of freshly chopped
parsley for these kind of slow cook
stews I do like a little bit of fresh
herb at the end just to brighten things
up and then as I teased earlier we're
gonna finish this off with a little bit
of horseradish snow just some fresh
horseradish root which you can grate
over using a fine cheese grater and if
you're not familiar with it it looks
like this kind of ugly but you peel off
that skin and it has a beautiful white
inside which you can grate over using a
microplane and by the way that's
actually pretty easy to find in the
supermarket just go to that section in
the produce department where they have
all the stuff that nobody buys it'll be
right there you can't miss it
so grate some of that over which of
course is going to mimic freshly fallen
snow and at that point our beef and
barley stew is done and I'm always
hungry filming these videos well
actually I'm always hungry all the time
but I could not wait to dig into this
and I was beyond thrilled with how this
came out that gorgeous tender beef that
sauce really gets enhanced by all that
bone marrow that kind of melts into it
as it cooks and then of course we have
our barley with that beautiful slightly
sweet slightly nutty earthy flavor just
such a perfect pairing with that sticky
beef and above and beyond looking cool
that little touch of horseradish really
amplifies the flavors and I really do
love living in California but this is
one of those recipes is I'm eating it I
actually missed the snow but then I
remember shoveling the driveways and
that
quickly passes but anyway the point is
if you're in the mood for something warm
and comforting or you just want a little
change of pace from the corn rice sweet
potato routine and I really hope you
give this beef and barley stew a try
soon so head over to food wishes calm
for all the ingredient amounts and more
info as usual and as always enjoy
